title: Creating gradients
summary: A 2 minute way of designing a beautiful and creative gradient wallpaper

body.raw:
Recently, more and more people have a gradient wallpaper. I enjoy them and they even inspire me creatively.

## Here's what you need:

- **A design app**, like [Figma](https://www.figma.com) - the one that I'm using - [Framer](https://framer.com), [Adobe XD](https://www.adobe.com/products/xd.html), [Sketch](https://www.sketch.com) or any other tool you want.
- **A color palette**, about 5-6 color choices for your awesome gradient.

## The process:

### Step One

Create a frame, I'll make a 5K one with the resolution of `5120 x 2880px`, but you can choose any resolution you want.

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-frame.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>

### Step Two

Create an eclipse and prepare your color palette.

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-eclipse.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>

### Step Three

Add your color palete using an angular gradient style. Make sure that the colors blend in and that the first and the last colors match. Here's an example:

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-eclipse-gradient.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>

### Step Four

Add a layer blur effect. The intensity should be based on the main colors of your eclipse.

**Darker colors**, like in my example, should have an intensity between _250-550_. **Lighter colors** should have an intensity around _400-700_.

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-eclipse-blur.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>

## Step Five

Resize. Make your eclipse bigger than the frame, rotate it, change the shape (like in the example), and play around with it until you achieve something that you like.

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-eclipse-resize.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>

### Step Six (optional)

If you want, you can duplicate the fill layer, and change the blending mode to `hard light` for a more lively effect.

This is our end product!

<Image
  alt='frame'
  src={`/static/images/gradients/figma-hard-light.png`}
  width={1680}
  height={975}
  className='rounded-lg'
/>
